sentence-detokenized: EU rejects German call for boycott of British lamb.
Peter Blackburn
Brussels 1996-08-22
The European Commission said on Thursday it disagreed with Germany's advice to consumers to avoid British lamb until scientists determine whether mad cow disease can be transmitted to sheep.

Werner Zwingmann, Germany's representative to the European Union's veterinary committee, said on Wednesday that consumers should buy lamb from countries other than the UK until scientific advice is clearer.
"We do not support any such proposal because we do not see any justification for it," Nicolas van der Pas, the commission's chief spokesman, said at a press conference.
He said further scientific research was needed and if it was found that action was needed, it should be taken by the EU.

He said that the proposal made last month by EU Agriculture Commissioner Franz Fischler to ban sheep brains, spleens and spinal cords from the human and animal food chain was a highly specific and preventive move to protect human health.

Fischler proposed the EU-wide measures following reports from the UK and France that sheep could be infected with bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), a mad cow disease, under laboratory conditions.

However, Fischler agreed to review his proposal after the EU Permanent Veterinary Committee (national animal health officials) questioned whether such action was justified as there was only a slight risk to human health.
Spanish Agriculture Minister Loyola de Palacio had earlier accused Fischler of causing unwarranted panic through "dangerous generalisations" at a meeting of EU agriculture ministers.
Only France and Great Britain supported Fechler's proposal.
The EU's Scientific Veterinary and Multidisciplinary Committee will revisit the issue early next month and make recommendations to senior veterinary officials.
It has long been known that sheep can contract pruritus, a brain disease similar to mad cow disease, which is believed to be transferred to cattle through feed containing animal waste.

British farmers denied on Thursday that their sheep posed any risk to human health, but expressed concern that the German government's advice to consumers to avoid British lamb could affect consumers across Europe.
"What we have to be very careful about is how other countries will accept German leadership," said John Lloyd Jones, president of the National Farmers' Union (NFU) in Wales, on BBC Radio.
In March, Bonn led efforts to protect public health after a British report suggested that humans could contract a mad cow disease-like illness from eating contaminated beef.
Germany imported 47,600 sheep from the UK last year, accounting for almost half of the total imports.
It brought in 4,275 tonnes of British lamb, representing approximately 10% of total imports.
A rare draft of a Hendrix song sells for almost $17,000.
A rare early handwritten draft of a song by American guitar legend Jimi Hendrix sold for nearly $17,000 at Thursday's auction of some of the late musician's favourite items.
A Florida restaurant paid £10,925 ($16,935) for a draft of 'Ain't no telling', which Hendrix wrote on a piece of letterhead in a London hotel in late 1966.
At the end of a concert in Nottingham, England, in January 1967, he threw the piece of paper into the audience, where it was picked up by a fan.
Buyers also snapped up 16 other items auctioned by Hendrix's ex-girlfriend Kathy Etchingham, who lived with Hendrix from 1966 to 1969.
These included a black lacquer and mother-of-pearl inlaid box used by Hendricks to store the drugs, which an anonymous Australian buyer bought for £5,060 ($7,845).
The guitarist died of a drug overdose in 1970 at the age of 27.
China says Taiwan is spoiling the mood of the talks.
Beijing 1996-08-22
China accused Taipei on Thursday of spoiling the atmosphere for the resumption of talks across the Taiwan Strait, with Taiwanese Vice President Lien Chan visiting Ukraine this week, angering Beijing.

Foreign Ministry spokesman Shen Guofang told Reuters hours after Chinese state media said the time was ripe for political talks with Taiwan." The necessary atmosphere for opening talks has been spoiled by the Taiwanese authorities."
State media quoted China's top negotiator with Taipei, Tang Shubi, as telling a visiting delegation from Taiwan on Wednesday that it was time for the rivals to hold political talks.
"It is time for political negotiations between the two sides. ......
That would be an end to hostilities," Tang was quoted as saying in Thursday's People's Daily overseas edition.

In an interview with Reuters TV, the Foreign Ministry's Shen said he had seen reports of Tang's comments, but did not elaborate on why the negotiator thought now was the time to negotiate with Taiwan, which Beijing considers a renegade province.
China, which has long opposed all efforts by Taipei to gain greater international recognition, was angered by the visit to Ukraine this week of Taiwanese Vice President Lien Chan.
China says now is a good time for Taiwan talks.
Beijing 1996-08-22
China says it is time for political talks with Taiwan and that the hostile island should take practical steps to achieve that goal.

The official Xinhua news agency quoted Tang Shubi, executive vice president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, as saying late Wednesday that consultations should be held to determine the timing and format of the talks.
German car registrations up 14.2 per cent year-on-year in July
Frankfurt 1996-08-22
First-time registrations of motor vehicles in Germany jumped 14.2 percent in July this year compared to the same month last year, the country's Federal Motor Vehicle Office said on Thursday.
The office said 356,725 new vehicles were registered in July 1996 - 304,850 passenger cars and 15,613 trucks.
These figures show an increase of 13.6% for passenger cars and a decrease of 2.2% for trucks compared to July 1995.
During this period, motorbike registrations increased by 32.7%.
The federal office said the increase was partly due to more Germans buying German cars abroad, while manufacturers said domestic demand was weak.
During this period, almost all German car manufacturers posted an increase in registrations.
Volkswagen won 77,719 registrations, just over a quarter of the total.
Opel came second with General Motors with 49,269 registrations, accounting for 16.4% of the overall figure.
Third place went to Ford with 35,563 registrations, or 11.7%.
Only Seat and Porsche registered fewer registrations in July 1996 compared to last July.
Seat posted 3,420 registrations, compared to 5,522 registrations in July a year ago.
Porsche registrations fell from 643 to 554 units.
Greek socialists gave the green light for the election of the Prime Minister.

The General Secretary of the Socialist Party of Greece, Costas Skandalidis, told reporters that the Executive Board of the Socialist Party of Greece gave the green light to Prime Minister Costas Simitis to hold emergency elections.
Prime Minister Costas Simitis will make an official announcement after a cabinet meeting later on Thursday, Skandalidis said.
-- Dimitris Kontogiannis, Athens Press Room +301 3311812-4

Israel downplays fears of war with Syria.
Colleen Siegel
Jerusalem 1996-08-22
Israel's outgoing peace negotiator with Syria said on Thursday that the current tensions between the two countries appeared to be a storm in a teacup.
Itamar Rabinovich, who as Israel's ambassador to Washington has engaged in inconclusive negotiations with Syria, told Israel Radio that it appears Damascus wants to negotiate rather than fight.
"In my view, {(1)[MISC] Syria's priority} remains to negotiate.
The Syrians are confused, they're definitely nervous, but the overall assessment here in Washington is that it's basically a storm in a teacup," he said.
Rabinovic is ending his term as ambassador.
He will be replaced by Eliyahu Ben-Elisar, the former Israeli envoy to Egypt and a politician from the right-wing Likud party.
Israel sent a message to Syria through Washington on Wednesday, saying it was committed to peace and wanted to start negotiations without preconditions.
But it slammed Damascus for creating what it called a dangerous atmosphere.
Syria accused Israel on Wednesday of launching a hysterical campaign against it after Israeli television reported that Damascus had recently test-fired a missile.
It stated that the weapons it purchased were for defensive purposes.
"Our message to (Syrian President Hafez Assad) is that Israel is ready to enter peace talks without preconditions," Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy said in an interview with Israel Radio.
Tensions have been rising since Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu took office in June, vowing to retain the Golan Heights, which Israel seized from Syria in the 1967 Middle East war.
Since 1991, peace talks between Israel and Syria have been deadlocked over the Golan, despite the former government's willingness to make concessions to the Golan.
The last peace talks between the two sides were held in February.
"The sound coming out of Damascus is bad, not good.
Media...
Full of expressions and statements that must worry people ......
This artificial atmosphere is very dangerous because those who spread it can become its prisoners," Levy said.
"We expect Syria," he said, "if it is faced with peace, it will respond to Israel's message and enter into peace negotiations, because that is our goal."
We don't want a war, God forbid.
No one benefited from the war."
Israel's Channel 2 television said Damascus had sent a "signal of calm" to Israel.
It did not provide the source of the report.
Spokesmen for Netanyahu and Levy said they could not confirm.
The TV station also said Netanyahu had sent a message through Cairo, the United States and Moscow to reassure Syria.
Polish diplomat denies having nurses stranded in Libya.

A Polish diplomat on Thursday denied a report in a Polish tabloid this week that Libya had denied exit visas to 100 Polish nurses who were trying to return home after working in the North African country.
"It's not true.

Tadeusz Awdankiewicz, head of the Polish embassy in Tripoli, told Reuters by telephone: "As of today, we are not aware of any nurse being held in Libya without her will, and we have not received any complaints.

Poland's Ministry of Labour said this week that it would send a team to Libya to investigate, but Adankiewicz said the investigation was prompted by complaints from some nurses about their working conditions, such as the non-payment of their salaries.
He said there were an estimated 800 Polish nurses working in Libya.
Two Iranian opposition leaders meet in Baghdad.
Hassan Hafidh
Baghdad 1996-08-22
An Iraq-based Iranian exile group vowed Thursday to provide support to Iranian Kurdish rebels after they were attacked by Iranian forces deep in Iraq last month.

A MKO statement said its leader Massoud Rajavi met with Hassan Rastegar, secretary general of the Democratic Party of Iranian Kurdistan, in Baghdad on Wednesday and expressed support for Iran's rebellious Kurds.
"Rajavi stressed that the Iranian resistance will continue to fight alongside its fellow Kurds and the resistance movement in Iranian Kurdistan," the report said.
A spokesman for the group said the meeting "marked a new level of cooperation between the Mujahideen and the Iranian Kurdish opposition".
Iran carried out heavy bombing of targets in northern Iraq in July in pursuit of KDPI guerrillas based in Iraqi Kurdish areas outside government control in Baghdad.
The Kurdish region of Iraq bordering Iran is under the control of guerrillas organised by the Patriotic Union of Iraqi Kurdistan (PUK).
The Kurdistan Democratic Party (KDP) and the two main Kurdish factions in Iraq have controlled northern Iraq since Iraqi forces were driven out of Kuwait in the 1991 Gulf War.
Clashes between the two parties erupted at the weekend in the worst fighting since the US-backed ceasefire last year.
The Khalq Mujahideen said Iranian forces had also been shelling KDP positions in the Qasri area of Sulaymaniyah province near the Iranian border for the past two days.
It said about 100 Iraqi Kurds had been killed or injured in the attack.
Both Iran and Turkey have conducted air and land strikes against targets in northern Iraq in pursuit of their own Kurdish rebels.
The US-led air force is in southern Turkey to protect Iraqi Kurds from possible attacks by Baghdad's army.
The Saudi Riyal exchange rate remained stable during a quiet summer of trading.
The Saudi Riyal spot rate against the US dollar and the Riyal interbank deposit rate remained mainly stable during a quiet summer session this week, dealers in the Kingdom said.
"There was no change in the Saudi Riyal exchange rate.
The market was very quiet due to the summer holidays," said one dealer.
The spot rial is trading at 3.7504 / 06 against the US dollar.
One-month interbank deposits are 5-1/2 at 3/8%, three-months are 5-5/8 at 1/2% and six-months are 5-3/4 at 5/8%.
One-year funding at 6,5-7/8%.
Israel approves Arafat's flight to the West Bank.
Jerusalem 1996-08-22
Israel on Thursday allowed Palestinian President Yasser Arafat to fly over its territory to the West Bank, ending a brief Israeli-PLO crisis, an adviser to Arafat said.
"The issue is over.
The president's plane has been given permission to pass through Israeli airspace, but the president is not expected to travel to the West Bank before Monday," Nabil Abu Radina told Reuters.

Arafat was scheduled to meet former Israeli Prime Minister Shimon Peres in the West Bank town of Ramallah on Thursday, but the venue was changed to Gaza after Israel refused to provide a flight permit for the Palestinian leader's helicopter.
Palestinian officials have accused right-wing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of trying to stop the Ramallah conference by grounding Arafat.
Arafat then cancelled a meeting between Israeli and PLO officials at the Allenby Bridge crossing between Jordan and the West Bank on civil matters.
Abu Rdainah said Arafat decided not to fly to the West Bank on the Thursday after Israel lifted the ban because he had a busy schedule in Gaza and would not be available until Monday.
Arafat to meet Peres in Gaza after flight ban
Jerusalem 1996-08-22

Yasser Arafat will meet Shimon Peres in Gaza on Thursday after Palestinians said Israel's right-wing government had banned the Palestinian leader from flying to the West Bank for talks with the former prime minister.

Japan's Finance Minister Wataru Kubo told a press conference on Wednesday that he sees no change in the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) interest rate policy aimed at ensuring economic growth following the release of the central bank's "tankan" survey report.
